snippet::array-coerce.description: You can use a combination of a ternary operator and Array.isArray to make sure a value, undefined, null or an array is always returned as an array.

snippet::array-difference.description: You can use a combination of filter and includes to calculate the difference between two arrays.

snippet::array-from-count.description: You can use `Array.from` to create an array of sequential integers

snippet::array-last.description: You can use arr.at(-1) if supported or arr[arr.length - 1] to get the last element of an array.

snippet::array-slice-exclude-last-n.description: You can get all but the last n elements using `array.slice`

snippet::array-union.description: You can use a combination of the spread operator and Set to create a union of two arrays.

snippet::array-unique.description: You can convert to and from a Set to remove duplicates from an array.

snippet::base64.description: Every modern runtime provides a way to convert byte array to and from base64.

snippet::call-bind.description: Every modern runtime provides a way to bind to the call method of a function.

snippet::get-iterator.description: Every modern runtime provides a way to get the iterator function through the Symbol.iterator symbol.

snippet::has-argv.description: You can use the includes method on the process.argv array to check if a flag is present.

snippet::is-arraybuffer.description: You can use `instanceof ArrayBuffer`, or if cross-realm, use Object.prototype.toString.call(obj) === "[object ArrayBuffer]"

snippet::is-boolean.description: You can use typeof to check if a value is a boolean primitive, and Object.prototype.toString.call to check if it's a Boolean object.

snippet::is-ci.description: Every major CI provider sets a CI environment variable that you can use to detect if you're running in a CI environment.

snippet::is-date.description: You can use `instanceof Date`, or if cross-realm, use Object.prototype.toString.call(v) === "[object Date]"

snippet::is-even.description: You can use the modulo operator to check if a number is even.

snippet::is-negative.description: You can check if a number is less than 0 to determine if it's negative.

snippet::is-negative-zero.description: You can use `Object.is` to check if a value is negative zero.

snippet::is-npm.description: If the current environment is npm the `npm_config_user_agent` environment variable will be set and start with "npm".

snippet::is-object.description: You can use `typeof` to check if a value is an object and `Object.getPrototypeOf` to ensure it's a plain object.
snippet::is-object.example: const isObject = (obj) => obj && typeof obj === "object" && (Object.getPrototypeOf(obj) === null || Object.getPrototypeOf(obj) === Object.prototype);

snippet::is-odd.description: You can use the modulo operator to check if a number is odd.

snippet::is-primitve.description: You can check `typeof` of a value to determine if it's a primitive. Note that `typeof null` is "object" so you need to check for null separately.
snippet::is-primitve.example: const isPrimitive = (value) => value === null || (typeof value !== "function" && typeof value !== "object");

snippet::is-regexp.description: You can use `instanceof RegExp` to check if a value is a regular expression, or if cross-realm, use `Object.prototype.toString.call(v) === "[object RegExp]"`.

snippet::is-stream.description: `node:stream` provides `isReadable` and `isWritable` methods that can be used to check if a stream is readable or writable.
snippet::is-stream.example:
import { isReadable, isWritable } from 'node:stream';
const isStream = (stream) => isReadable(stream) || isWritable(stream);

snippet::is-string.description: You can use `typeof` to check if a value is a string.

snippet::is-symbol.description: You can use `typeof` to check if a value is a symbol.

snippet::is-travis.description: You can check if the current environment is Travis CI by checking if the `TRAVIS` environment variable is set.

snippet::is-whitespace.description: You can check if a string contains only whitespace with RegExp or by trimming it and comparing it to an empty string.

snippet::is-windows.description: You can check if the current environment is Windows by checking if `process.platform` is equal to "win32".

snippet::math-random.description: You can use `Math.random()` or `crypto.getRandomValues` if cryptographic randomness is required.

snippet::object-filter.description: You can use `Object.fromEntries` with `Object.entries` and `Array.prototype.filter` to filter an object's properties.

snippet::object-map.description: You can use `Object.fromEntries` with `Object.entries` and `Array.prototype.map` to map an object's properties.
snippet::object-map.example: const objectMap = (obj, fn) => Object.fromEntries(Object.entries(obj).map(([k, v]) => fn(k, v)));

snippet::regexp-copy.description: You can create a copy of a regular expression using the `RegExp` constructor.

snippet::set-tostringtag.description: You can set the `toStringTag` of an object using `Object.defineProperty`.
snippet::set-tostringtag.example: const setToStringTag = (target, value) => Object.defineProperty(target, Symbol.toStringTag, { value, configurable: true });

snippet::split-lines.description: You can split a string into lines using a regular expression.

snippet::to-lower.description: You can convert a string to lowercase using `toLocaleLowerCase` or `toLowerCase`.

snippet::to-uppercase.description: You can convert a string to uppercase using `toLocaleUpperCase` or `toUpperCase`.

snippet::typeof.description: You can use `typeof` to get the type of a value, or `Object.prototype.toString.call` to get the internal [[Class]] of an object.

snippet::unix-paths.description: You can check the start of a path for the Windows extended-length path prefix and if it's not present, replace backslashes with forward slashes.

snippet:is-number.description: You can check if a value is a number by using `typeof` or coercing it to a number and using `Number.isFinite`.
snippet:is-number.example: const isNumber = (v) => typeof v === "number" || (typeof v === "string" && Number.isFinite(+v));
